summary: A letter from Smith Villazor LLP to Judge Alison J. Nathan regarding compliance with a court order in the United States v. Maxwell case. The letter, written on behalf of the independent administrator of the Epstein Victims' Compensation Program, requests an extension to produce subpoenaed documents, citing a volume of 6,000-7,000 pages.

persons.name: Alison J. Nathan
persons.context: The presiding judge in the Southern District of New York to whom the letter is addressed regarding the document production order in the United States v. Maxwell case.

persons.name: Maxwell
persons.context: The defendant in the case (United States v. Maxwell) who issued a subpoena to the administrator of the Epstein Victims' Compensation Program.

connections.description: Judge Nathan is presiding over the criminal case against Maxwell and issued the order compelling document production.

events.title: Court Denies Motion to Quash Subpoena
events.description: Judge Nathan issued an order denying the motion to quash Maxwell's subpoena to the administrator of the Epstein Victims' Compensation Program and ordered production of documents by November 24, 2021, at noon.

events.title: Initial Document Production Deadline
events.description: The court-ordered deadline for the administrator to produce subpoenaed documents to Maxwell.

events.title: Original Subpoena Return Date / Requested Extension
events.description: The original return date for Maxwell's subpoena was 8:30 a.m. The letter requests an extension to complete full document production by this date.

locations: 40 Foley Square, New York, New York 10007
250 West 55th Street, 30th Floor, New York, NY 10019
keyFacts: The independent administrator of the Epstein Victims' Compensation Program was ordered to comply with a subpoena from Ghislaine Maxwell.
The volume of potentially responsive materials is approximately 6,000 to 7,000 pages.
The administrator intended to produce claim forms, narratives, payment records, and releases for four specific individuals by the initial deadline.
The letter requests an extension to complete production by the original subpoena return date of November 29, 2021.
The document reveals ongoing discovery efforts in Maxwell's criminal case, specifically targeting records from the victim compensation program.
